prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

para.paratext: An order for transfer essentially transfers the case to the transferee court in its procedural posture on the date of transfer. Any motions or other matters pending in the transferor court are transferred for consideration by the transferee court. The transferor court is without jurisdiction to enter rulings on such motions once transfer is ordered.[1]

The rulings that have already been made by the transferor court have a less concrete status. Orders entered by the transferor court continue to be binding on the parties.[2] The Panel has specifically expressed its preference that any case management orders entered by the transferor court be followed after transfer.[3] The transferor court has the discretion, however, to modify those orders. This power is not surprising, since the transferor court would, in most cases, have the power to change, revoke, or amend any of its own interlocutory pretrial orders.[4] The transferor court's orders are not treated as law of the case.[5] They may be reviewed by the transferee court under the highly deferential standards of the law of the case doctrine. This application of the law of the case doctrine is consistent with the deference normally required of transferor court upon remand following proceedings in the transferee court.[6] One very significant change in circumstance arises whenever transfer occurs: the Panel has centralized cases from at least two districts—and usually many more—and directed the transferee judge to manage them as a group. This mandate frequently requires, and certainly allows— modification of earlier orders entered by judges in a smaller subset of the cases.[7]
The Panel also recognizes that orders made in one of the transferred cases may be made applicable to other parties and actions by the transferee judge.[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Aircrash Near Duarte, California, On June 6, 1971, 357 F. Supp. 1013 (C.D. Cal. 1973).
See, e.g., In re Penn Central Securities Litigation, 62 F.R.D. 181 (E.D. Pa. 1974); In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 297 F. Supp. 385, 386 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
See, e.g., In re Master Key, 320 F. Supp. 1404, 1407 (J.P.M.L. 1971).

See In re Long Distance Telecommunication Litigation, 612 F. Supp. 892, 900–04 (E.D. Mich. 1985), judgment aff'd in part, rev'd in part on other grounds, 831 F.2d 627 (6th Cir. 1987) (law of case doctrine did not bar transferee court reconsideration of prior decision). The court in Certified Collateral quoted from In re Multi-Piece Rim Products Liability Litigation, 653 F.2d 671 (D.C. Cir. 1981), where the court stated:

The transferee judge's authority to coordinate consolidated pretrial proceedings in multidistrict cases is the essential contribution of the multidistrict transfer procedure. That judge has the power to set aside pretrial rulings of the transferor courts, and courts performing auxiliary roles must be guided by the transferee judge's rulings.

612 F.2d at 902. See also In re Korean Air Lines Disaster of Sept. 1, 1983, 829 F.2d 1171 (D.C. Cir. 1987), judgment aff'd, 490 U.S. 122, 109 S. Ct. 1676, 104 L. Ed. 2d 113 (1989). For a thorough and thoughtful analysis of the application of the doctrine of law of the case to multidistrict transfer situations, see Joan Steinman, Law of the Case: A Judicial Puzzle in Consolidated and Transferred Cases and in Multidistrict Litigation, 135 U. Pa. L. Rev. 595, 672–84 (1987). For a general discussion of the power of courts to modify orders generally, see David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Motion Practice§ 2.06 (8th ed. 2018).

In re Pharmacy Benefit Managers Antitrust Litigation, 582 F.3d 432 (3d Cir. 2009) (applying law of the case doctrine to evaluate propriety of transferee court's vacating of prior decisions of transferor court); In re Korean Air Lines Disaster of Sept. 1, 1983, 829 F.2d 1171 (D.C. Cir. 1987), judgment aff'd, 490 U.S. 122, 109 S. Ct. 1676, 104 L. Ed. 2d 113 (1989). In this decision, the court held that the law of the circuit in which the transferee court is located would not be binding on the transferor court. See also Sentner v. Amtrak, 540 F. Supp. 557 (D.N.J. 1982) (transferor court required to adhere to orders of the transferor court by law of case doctrine).
See, e.g., In re Ford Motor Co., 591 F.3d 406 (5th Cir. 2009). The effect of prior rulings upon remand is discussed in greater detail in § 10:17.
See, e.g., In re Oreck Corporation Halo Vacuum and Air Purifiers Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 282 F.R.D. 486 490–91 (C.D. Cal. 1012).

See, e.g., In re Delta Airlines Crash at Boston, Massachusetts, on July 31, 1973, 395 F. Supp. 1405, 1407 (J.P.M.L. 1975) (“Of course, any discovery involving the United States heretofore completed in the transferee district may be made applicable to Moore by appropriate orders of the transferee court. See Manual for Complex Litigation, Part I,§ 3.11 (1973).”).
